content: https://micah-zoltu.medium.com/what-does-a-miner-revolt-look-like-a99216fe270e gives a high level overview, but doesn't go into too much technical detail.

author: potuz
content: Read that yesterday when you posted it. It's an interesting description of attacks but what it lacks is measure like what's the cost per hour to maintain an attack currently with rented hashrate for example? What is the impact on miners revenue if eth prices go down because of an attack? Without some hard numbers I just don't see how can it be justified the entire network paying. Adrian makes a good point that this by itself is a successful attack

author: sky.cactus
content: The impact on miner revenue in the naive transition is quite low, and possibly negative (meaning it is profitable for them).

author: sky.cactus
content: I think calling this a "successful attack" is quite unfair.  No one has done anything *except* describe a way in which the network is economically insecure during the transition.  Telling your neighbor that their gate is open isn't an attack against your neighbor's house.

author: sky.cactus
content: I do agree that we need better data on the impact of a 51% attack near the merge so we can be sure we don't over or under pay for security.
